Fig. 4 XPS spectrum for O1s of the prepared catalysts. Fig. 5 XPS spectrum for V2p of V1.5Ti. Fig. 6 XPS spectrum for V2p of V1.5W3Ti, V1.5W6Ti and V1.5W9Ti. Fig. 7 PL spectra of V1.5Ti and V1.5W6Ti. Fig. 11 Effect of NO2/NO x on the catalytic activity of V1.5W x Ti. Promotional effect of WO3 on O2 − over V2O5/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 Shule Zhang Qin Zhong * School of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, PR China School of Chemical Engineering Nanjing University of Science and Technology Nanjing 210094 PR China * Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 25 84315517, fax: +86 25 84315517. Graphical abstract Promotional effect of WO3 on the formation of O2 − over V2O5/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 was studied. The aim of this novel design was to investigate the role of tungsten species in electrons transfer over the ternary VWTi catalysts. Analysis by XRD, XPS, PL and EPR showed that WO3 species improved the electrons transfer of the catalysts to facilitate the formation of reduced V2O5 that was important to improve the formation of superoxide ions. This property was remarkably different from that of the VTi catalyst and it could contribute to a new understanding of the catalytic behavior of VWTi catalyst in low-temperature SCR processes. Keywords WO3 O2 − Reduced V2O5 VWTi catalyst SCR 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) remain a major source of air pollution. It contributes to photochemical smog, acid rain, ozone depletion and greenhouse effect [1]. At present, the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NO x with NH3 in the presence of excess oxygen has been proven to be an efficient process for the removal of NO x from stationary sources [1–3]. For a long time, scientists have tried a variety of catalyst systems, such as V2O5–WO3/TiO2 [4–6], CeO2/TiO2 [7], Mn/TiO2 [8] and many metal composite oxide catalysts [9,10]. Among these catalysts, V2O5–WO3/TiO2 has good SO2 and H2O resistance and they have almost no effect on the NO reduction at high temperature, therefore V2O5–WO3/TiO2 has been applied as an industrial catalyst for many years [11–13]. Many researches have reported the effects of WO3 in V2O5–WO3/TiO2 are that: (1) WO3 inhibits the initial sintering of TiO2 [14], (2) WO3 increases the amount of Lewis acid over catalyst [15], (3) the temperature window for SCR reaction is greatly widened [4], (4) WO3 improves SO2 resistance [16]. Efforts have been made to study performance of V2O5–WO3/TiO2 such as 1%V2O5–9%WO3/TiO2 [4], 1%V2O5–10%WO3/TiO2 [5], 3%V2O5–9%WO3/TiO2 [6], 1.7–2.5%V2O5–8% WO3/TiO2 [17,18], Ce-doped 0.1%V2O5–6%WO3/TiO2 [19]. However, these catalysts have been not investigated the promotional reason of WO3 on improving the NO conversion at low-temperature of V2O5/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3. More studies are revealing that the nitro and nitrate groups are the intermediates that react with adsorbed ammonia for SCR process at low temperatures [20–22]. Furthermore, it has been reported that superoxide ions over the catalysts are important to enhance the formation of nitro and nitrate groups [20,23]. Therefore, the aim of this study is to investigate the improvement of WO3 in SCR catalyst from the aspect of superoxide ions. To the best of our knowledge, promotional effect of WO3 on O2 − over V2O5/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 has not yet been studied. In this study, we found that an appropriate amount of WO3 could improve the transformation of electron to enhance the reduce V2O5 (V4+ and V3+) that improve the formation of superoxide ions. This aspect is the reason that WO3 could improve the NO conversion of V2O5/TiO2 at low-temperature. Therefore the information in this paper would contribute to a better understanding of the low-temperature SCR processes over V2O5–WO3/TiO2 catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The V2O5/WO3/TiO2 catalyst was prepared by a sol–gel method for TiO2 preparation, followed by impregnation for WO3 and then V2O5, specifically as follows: Ti(OC4H9)4 (0.064mol) was stabilized by adding 0.128mol acetylacetone under continuous stirring. After stirring for 2h at room temperature, the sol was concentrated in a 60°C water bath and subsequently dried at 120°C for 6h. The gel was calcined at 500°C for 3h in air. It is further referred to as W0Ti. After impregnation in ammonium wolframate solution (WO3 loadings were 3~9%) in a 60°C water bath and reflux for 4h, the sieved WTi was dried at 120°C for 6h and subsequently calcined at 500°C for 2h. It was further referred to as W x Ti. The ammonium metavanadate (V2O5 loadings were 1.5%) was first dissolved in 50ml deionized water at 80°C. Then the W x Ti was added under conditions of constant temperature and stirring. After 1h, the mixture was dried at 120°C for 6h and subsequently calcined at 500°C for 2h. Finally, the V2O5/WO3/TiO2 catalyst was obtained and it was further referred to as V1.5W x Ti. For example, V1.5W6Ti meant the catalyst with 1.5% V2O5 loadings and 6% WO3 loadings. 2.2 Catalytic activity tests The SCR of NO was carried out at 120–240°C in a fixed-bed flow reactor (i.d. 6.8mm) containing catalyst sample (100–120 mesh) under atmospheric pressure. The used mass of the catalyst was 0.3000g with quartz sand as inert. The gas flow was controlled by mass flow meters. The reaction temperature was measured by a type K thermocouple inserted into the catalyst bed. The reactant gas consisted of 500ppm NO, 600ppm NH3, 5% O2 and balanced N2 at a flow rate of 150mL/min for accurately reflecting the promoting effect of WO3 on the NO conversion over the test catalysts. Each catalyst sample was adsorbed by the reaction mixture before the reaction for avoiding errors caused by NO adsorption on the catalyst. All of the catalysts were kept on stream at each temperature for 1h. The NO and NO2 concentration in the inlet and outlet gas was measured by a MRUVARIOPLUS flue gas analyzer (Germany). 2.3 Characterization The distribution of tungsten species over the samples were determined by X-ray diffractometry (Purkinje General Instrument Co., Ltd, China, XD-3). XPS experiments were carried out on a RBD upgraded PHI-5000C ESCA system (Perkin Elmer) with Mg Kα radiation (hν =1253.6eV), calibrated by the C 1s peak at 284.6eV with an accuracy of ±0.2eV. The electron transformation of the prepared catalysts were characterized by photoluminescence (PL) spectra at room temperature using a Labram-HR800-type spectrophotometer (Jobin Yvon Co., France) with a He–Cd laser (λ =325nm) as the light source. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were made at room temperature using a Bruker EMX-10/12-type spectrometer in the X-band. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity tests Fig. 1 shows NO conversion for the prepared catalysts. The NO conversion of all the prepared catalysts increased significantly with increasing temperature below 300°C. Among these catalysts, V1.5Ti showed low catalytic activity. The NO conversion of V1.5Ti was only 57.1% and 84.0% at 240°C and 270°C, respectively. Furthermore, the NO conversion of V1.5Ti decreased clearly above 300°C. Therefore, the temperature window of the V1.5Ti was narrow. NO conversion promoted with the increase of WO3 loadings. For the V1.5W6Ti, the NO conversion increased to 76.8% and 95.2% at 240°C and 270°C, respectively, and almost no NO could be detected in the outlet of fixed-bed flow reactor above 300°C (300–360°C). Therefore, the catalytic activity of the VWTi catalyst was excellent and W could improve the NO conversion at low-temperature to expend the low-temperature window of the SCR catalyst. 3.2 Distribution of tungsten species Fig. 2 displays the X-ray diffraction patterns of the prepared catalysts. All the peaks of the prepared catalysts calcined at 500°C were anatase (2θ =25.5°, 37.1°, 48.3°, 54.1°, 55.3°, 62.8°, 70.3°, 75.3°) (PDF#21-1272), and faint rutile (PDF#21-1276) were observed, indicating that the TiO2 was mainly anatase and consists of a little anatase/rutile mixed crystal structure as the support by calcination at 500°C. Furthermore, there were no significant change and formation of new diffraction peak with the increase of WO3 loadings to 9%, which could conclude that the particle size and crystal phase have little change by WO3 loadings and no new solid solution of W x Ti1−x O2 was formed or at least that only trace amount of solid solution like W x Ti1−x O2 was formed in the process of catalyst preparation. It can also be seen from Fig. 2 that WO3 phase was not observed. It indicated that WO3 was well-dispersed over the support with the increase of WO3 loadings to 9%. 3.3 Element valences of VTi and VWTi catalysts Fig. 3 shows the XPS spectrum for Ti2p of the prepared catalysts, which consisted of double peaks (Ti 2p1/2 and 2p3/2). For the V1.5Ti, V1.5W3Ti and V1.5W6Ti, the binding energies of these peaks were 464.5 and 458.7eV, respectively. It indicated that Ti existed as the Ti4+ state as the WO3 loadings was from 0 to 6% over the V2O5/WO3/TiO2 catalysts. It could also be seen from Fig. 3 that Ti3+ state of the V1.5Ti, V1.5W3Ti and V1.5W6Ti was not observed and there was no shift in the Ti2p peaks of these catalysts, implying that WO3 had much no impact on cation of the catalyst carrier. For the V1.5W9Ti catalyst, a slight increase in binding energies was observed with Ti4+2p3/2 shifting to 458.8eV. Therefore, the titanium species in V1.5W9Ti catalyst had lower a density of the electron cloud than the catalysts with lower WO3 loadings. It indicated that W species were the electron withdrawing group compared with TiO2 over the V2O5/WO3/TiO2 catalysts. Fig. 4 displays the XPS spectrum for O1s of the prepared catalysts. The peak of V1.5Ti, V1.5W3Ti and V1.5W6Ti was at 530eV. It was attributed to the lattice oxygen (529.0–531.0eV [24,25]). It could also be seen from Fig. 4 that there was also no shift in the O1s peaks of V1.5Ti, V1.5W3Ti and V1.5W6Ti, and O1s peak of V1.5W9Ti shifted slightly to the high binding energy direction compared with other catalysts. It indicated that WO3 had little or no effect on anion of carrier. From these results, it was easy to know that W ions could not implant into the TiO2 lattice. This was consistent with our XRD results. Ke et al. have proposed that there was no interaction between WO3 and TiO2 before calcinations at 900°C [26]. More studies have also revealed that WO3 only wrapped on the surface of TiO2 with low amount in the most situations [27,28]. It indicated that appearance of reduced species was not caused by the W x Ti1−x O2 (If W ions had implanted into TiO2 lattice, it could have caused the charge compensation and it might have contributed to the formation of reduced species). The binding energies at 515.6, 516.2 and 516.9eV were attributed to V3+2p2/3, V4+2p2/3 and V5+2p2/3, respectively. Fig. 5 shows the XPS spectra for V2p of V1.5Ti. As shown in Fig. 5, V species were mainly with V5+ state and only a few species of V3+ state appeared. V4+ state was not detected in the V1.5Ti catalyst. These indicated that vanadium oxide existed mainly as quintavalent state and the other states were seldom in the VTi catalyst. Fig. 6 shows the XPS spectrum for V2p of V1.5W3Ti, V1.5W6Ti and V1.5W9Ti. V species were also mainly with V5+ state over the V1.5W3Ti, V1.5W6Ti and V1.5W9Ti catalysts. However, the amount of V3+ state increased and a large number of species of V4+ state formed and increased on the surface of the V2O5/WO3/TiO2 with WO3 loadings from 3 to 6%. As the WO3 loadings reached 9% (V1.5W9Ti), the amount of V3+ state increased and V4+ state was almost invariable compared with the V1.5W6Ti catalyst (Surface atomic ration of V4+/(V3+ +V4+ +V5+) of V1.5W6Ti and V1.5W9Ti was 30.9% and 30.6%, respectively). These indicated that W species could improve the formation of the reduced V2O5 (V3+ and V4+) over V2O5/WO3/TiO2 catalyst. A similar conclusion was drawn by Paganini et al. [29]. It has been reported that WO3 could store and transfer electrons over WO3–TiO2 catalysts in photocatalysis research [30,31]. Therefore, in the V2O5/WO3/TiO2 catalyst, WO3 could store electrons of the catalyst and transfer the electrons to V species to improve the formation of the reduced V2O5 (Eqs. (1)–(3)). The characterization that WO3 could improve to transfer electrons was confirmed by PL spectra in the next section. It is also noticed that the reduced V2O5 could be oxidized by oxygen and oxygen may be reduced to superoxide ions [32]. This means that VWTi might have better activity for the formation of superoxide ions. The superoxide ions over the catalysts are important to enhance the activity of low-temperature SCR of NO with NH3 [23,33]. The characterization of surface superoxide ions was confirmed by EPR spectra in Section 3.5. (1) V 5 + + e ⟶ WO 3 V 4 + (2) V 4 + e ⟶ WO 3 V 4 + (3) V 5 + + 2 e ⟶ WO 3 V 3 + 3.4 Effect of electrons transfer PL emission spectra have been widely used to investigate the efficiency of charge carrier trapping, migration, and transfer in order to understand the fate of electron–hole pairs in semiconductor particles since PL emission results from the recombination of free carriers [34]. In other words, a lower recombination rate of those electrons and holes or a higher transfer of electrons can result in a lower PL intensity. Many studies have reported PL emissions of TiO2 based catalyst in photocatalysis research [35,36]. Fig. 7 shows the PL spectra of V1.5Ti and V1.5W6Ti. The V1.5Ti and V1.5W6Ti samples can exhibit an obvious PL signal with a similar curve shape at the wavelength range from 500 to 600nm. The PL intensity of V1.5W6Ti sample was lower than that of the V1.5Ti. Similar quenching in the luminescence intensity was observed for WO x doped TiO2 by Li et al. [31]. According to Ke et al. when WO3 and TiO2 form a catalyst, the electrons can be transferred to the lower-lying conduction band of WO3 [26]. It was also noticed no W x Ti1−x O2 was formed on the surface of the catalyst (was confirmed in Section 3.2). Therefore, the decrease of PL intensity of V1.5W6Ti resulted from the higher effect of electrons transfer of WO3 (not because of W doping into the TiO2 lattice). Such observation was consistent with the results of our XPS results. 3.5 Characterization of surface superoxide ions For commercialized SCR processes at temperatures between 300 and 400°C, it is agreed that the reaction mechanism involves the interaction of adsorbed ammonia (NH4 +) with gaseous NO [16]. However, for SCR process at lower temperatures, increasingly more studies [22,37,38] are revealing that reactive NO y (nitro and nitrate) groups are the intermediates that react with adsorbed ammonia (most probably adsorbed onto Lewis acid sites [33,39]). Thus, the formation of NO y from gaseous NO is the key process. It has been reported that the NO y groups are formed from NO and an adsorbed superoxide ion [40]. Wang et al. [23] also proved that NO molecule could react with a superoxide ion to form NO y group in the SCR reaction by using in situ FT-IR spectroscopy. This important role of superoxide ions in the low-temperature SCR process has been confirmed by our group (Eqs. (4) and (5)) [20,32,33]. V1.5W x Ti with WO3 loadings might have better activity for the formation of superoxide ions than the V1.5Ti catalyst has been discussed in Section 3.3. Therefore, we also investigated the superoxide ion content on the catalyst surface. (4) NO + O 2 − → N O 3 − (5) NO + N O 3 − → 2 N O 2 − Fig. 8 shows the EPR spectrum of W0Ti (TiO2 matrix), W6Ti, V1.5Ti and V1.5W6Ti. Our previous study observed the signals at g =2.0061–2.0103 attributed the superoxide ions [32]. We detected the signals at g =2.0076 in this study. A few superoxide ions were observed on the W0Ti and the intensity of superoxide ions of the W0Ti sample was almost as same as the W6Ti. It indicated that a small amount of superoxide ions could form on the pure TiO2 matrix (Ti3+ defect is a formation site of superoxide ions on the TiO2 surface [41].) and the WO3 could not improve the formation of superoxide ions on the composite sample of WO3 and TiO2. For the V1.5Ti sample, the hyperfine splitting structure of V4+ due to the V nucleus (I =7/2, multiplicity 8) [4] was observed, but the intensity of V4+ was very weak, indicating that the amount of the reduced V2O5 was low. It was consistent with our XPS results (V4+ state was not observed by XPS spectra might be due to the low V4+ content.). It can also be seen from the EPR spectrum of V1.5Ti that the intensity of superoxide ions was weak. It indicated that the V2O5 could also not improve the formation of superoxide ions on the binary V1.5Ti sample. For the V1.5W6Ti catalyst, the intensity of the reduced V2O5 increased significantly. Such observation was consistent with the results of our XPS results. It was also noticed that the intensity of the reduced V2O5 and superoxide ions simultaneous increased significantly. It has been reported that V4+ and V3+ are a preferential formation site of superoxide ions [32,42]. Therefore, the reduced V2O5 resulted in the increase of the amounts of superoxide ions in our EPR tests (Eqs. (6)–(8)). (6) V 3 + + O 2 → V 4 + + O 2 − (7) V 3 + + 2 O 2 → V 5 + + 2 O 2 − (8) V 4 + + O 2 → V 5 + + O 2 − Fig. 9 shows the EPR spectrum for V1.5W x Ti with different WO3 loadings. The intensity of the reduced V2O5 and superoxide ions was simultaneously increased with the increase of WO3 loadings to 6%, indicating that the WO3 improved the formation of the reduced V2O5 and the reduced V2O5 was a preferential formation site of superoxide ions. As a further increasing the WO3 loadings (V1.5W9Ti sample), the intensity of the reduced V2O5 (V4+) was as same as the V1.5W6Ti sample. It indicated that the electrons transfer to the V2O5 species were limited by WO3 on the catalyst. It can also be seen that the amounts of the superoxide ions decreased. The amounts of superoxide ions of V1.5W9Ti were not attributed to factor that the overmuch of WO3 loadings caused tungsten species deposited on the catalyst surface, because WO3 was well-dispersed over the V1.5W9Ti catalyst, which has been discussed in Section 3.2. When the content of tungsten oxides was higher tungsten impurity energy level would be an electron recombination center [43]. It is also noticed that WO3 was an electron withdrawing and storage group. Therefore, excessive WO3 loadings might trap electrons to inhibit the formation of superoxide ions. 3.6 Activity of NO oxidation to NO2 It has been reported [7,9] that an increase in NO oxidation to NO2 would result in a significant improvement in the SCR activity. Furthermore, NO y groups could decompose to NO2 molecules with each other [23]. Therefore, it is necessary to investigate NO oxidation in the absence of NH3 on the different V2O5/WO3/TiO2 catalysts. Fig. 10 shows NO conversion to NO2 for V1.5W x Ti with different WO3 loadings. It can be seen that NO oxidation promoted clearly with the increase of the WO3 loadings to 6% and, as the WO3 loadings reached 9%, NO conversion to NO2 for V1.5W9Ti increased slightly. The trend of NO oxidation to NO2 of the catalysts was consistent with the activity and EPR tests as the WO3 loadings was from 0% to 6%. The above XPS and EPR results revealed that WO3 was helpful to the formation of reduced V2O5, and the reduced V2O5 promoted the amounts of superoxide ions, which were good for the NO oxidation. 3.7 Effect of NO2/NO x on the catalytic activity of V1.5W x Ti The primary nitrogen oxides produced from combustion processes with fossil fuel are NO and NO2 is less than one tenth of NO in the total nitrogen oxides emission from stationary sources such as thermoelectric power plant [44]. However, NO2 concentration is important to the low-temperature SCR activity [11,45,46]. WO3 could improve the NO oxidation to NO2, which has been discussed in Section 3.6. Therefore, we tested the effect of NO2/NO x on the catalytic activity of V1.5W x Ti under the condition of 0.3g catalyst, 240°C, 500ppm NO x (NO x =NO+NO2), 600ppm NH3, 5% O2 and balanced N2 at a flow rate of 150mL/min (Fig. 11 ). NO x conversion promoted with the increase of WO3 loadings at the NO2/NO x ratio of 0. The NO x conversion for all the V1.5W x Ti catalysts increased and was similar with each other at the NO2/NO x ratio of 0.25. Almost no NO x could be detected in the outlet of fixed-bed at the NO2/NO x ratio of 0.50. NO x conversion of the V1.5W x Ti catalysts increased significantly with increasing the NO2/NO x ratio form 0 to 0.50 since it boosted the low-temperature SCR activity thanks to the so-called “fast SCR” reaction (NO+NO2 +2NH3 →2N2 +3H2O), which is significantly more active than the “standard SCR” reaction (2NO+2NH3 +1/2O2 →2N2 +3H2O) below 250°C [45]. Furthermore, the increase rate for NO x conversion of all the V1.5W x Ti catalysts decreased with increasing WO3 loadings. In other words, effect of WO3 was less obvious as the NO2/NO x ratio tended to 0.50. Therefore, the WO3 improvement in NO conversion over V2O5/WO3/TiO2 catalyst at low-temperature was attributed that WO3 could improve the NO oxidation. The NO x conversion for all the V1.5W x Ti catalysts decreased clearly with the NO2/NO x ratio from 0.50 to 1.00. It might be attributed that reduction of NO2 with NH3 needed a higher stoichiometric NH3/NO2 ratio (2NO2 +4NH3 +O2 →3N2 +6H2O). 4 Conclusion The catalytic activity of NO removal was obviously expended the low-temperature window on the V1.5W x Ti catalysts for low-temperature SCR of NO with NH3. V1.5W x Ti with the WO3 loadings reached 6% showed the best activity. The superior performance of the catalysts could be attributed to that WO3 species improve the electrons transfer of the catalysts to facilitate the formation of reduced V2O5 (V4+ and V3+). This aspect resulted in the increase of the superoxide ions which were important to low-temperature SCR reaction. coredata.dc:description: Promotional effect of WO3 on the formation of O2 − over V2O5/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3 was studied. The aim of this novel design was to investigate the role of tungsten species in electrons transfer over the ternary VWTi catalysts. Analysis by XRD, XPS, PL and EPR showed that WO3 species improved the electrons transfer of the catalysts to facilitate the formation of reduced V2O5 that was important to improve the formation of superoxide ions. This property was remarkably different from that of the VTi catalyst and it could contribute to a new understanding of the catalytic behavior of VWTi catalyst in low-temperature SCR processes.
coredata.dc:title: Promotional effect of WO3 on O2 − over V2O5/TiO2 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3
